text: Is it possible to populate the fields of a module with data from a hubdb table?  I want the data in a hubdb table, however, also want non-technical content creators to still be able to upload the photos and content for that table within the Content/Edit GUI.  It seems like this would be a pretty essential feature, but, I haven't found any documentation on it.
I think you would wanting to use this field in your module: <https://developers.HubSpot.com/docs/cms/building-blocks/module-theme-fields#hubdb-row>

<@U2H3TT8F2> thanks for this, I'll play around with it and see if it's the solution we're looking for.  If I use a hubdb row field, does that allow the content creator to also update the values of the row or create new rows?  If so, then this is exactly what we need.
They won't be able to add or update rows but it does allow them to pull them in for displaying the rows.
Thank you very much <@UEC65BQV8> for your support.
You bet. Let me know if you have more questions

<@UEC65BQV8> <https://developers.HubSpot.com/docs/cms/building-blocks/templates/blog-template-markup> : this page talking about listing of hs default blog post , right ? if i say "create custom module that make blog post and listing" what would be approach; create custom module with adding fields like title , author, date, text, and show that posts in a page or create a module with hs default blog system , grab post list from hs blogs and make form with field for posting blog content to default hs blog. actually i am confused because i am very new in this platform. can you please direct me the steps for creating custom module that make blog. Pardon me for my english.

No worries. I think the confusion is you donâ€™t want to use modules at all. You have tempaltes for the blog post and listing. Then you create posts (and content and other and all those things) in the HubSpot blog editor
you kind of have to think of the blog as complete seperate from your website with pages and modules and such.

the blog is its own thing and only uses those two templates (post and listing). Modules are more like reusuable blocks or sections that can be put together to build a webpage templates, which thus then can be used to create actual pages with content.

so for webpages:
 `many modules -> tempalte + content = pages`
`templates + content = blog posts and blog listings`
You can create a custom module with a repeater for each section/row. Each section/row has a select option what kind of "Template" and function the user should get
